p: The repellency of A. majus (68.3%) essential oil towards tick I. ricinus in the present study could be explained by the presence of carvone, dihydrocarvone and piperitone. These three in combination are possible candidates for the repellent activity. The essential oil of F. vulgare consisted of only six compounds contributing more than 98% of the oil. Limonene, p-allylanisole, and fenchone were the most abundant compounds in this essential oil that could be responsible for its biological activity. Limonene is used as an insecticide to control ectoparasites and has activity against many plant-feeding insects as the pine weevil (Nordlander 1990), mites and microorganisms (Ibrahim et al. 2001). Fenchone is reported to show mosquito repellent activity (Kim et al. 2002).
